titleInfo.title: LSU History Oral History Project: Alumni
titleInfo.subTitle: Thomas Fuller Ruffin oral history interview, 2000-2005.

name.description: "Thomas Fuller Ruffin was born in Shreveport, La., in 1925, and graduated from C.E. Byrd High School. He served with the U.S. Navy during World War II in the Atlantic, Caribbean, and Pacific, and continued to serve in China after the war. Ruffin graduated from Louisiana State University with a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering in 1947. He was the president of Ruffin Brick Co. and Ruffin Transportation, Inc., then worked for four decades in the stock brokerage industry, retiring as Vice President of Smith Barney, Inc. Ruffin served on the board of many organizations during his lifetime, including the Volunteers of America, the LSU Athletic Council, and the Louisiana Historical Association. He also served as National Vice President of the U.S. Jaycees. Ruffin published over 75 articles on the history of the Ark-La-Tex area, and was the author of ""Under Stately Oaks: A Pictorial History of LSU."" He was married to Joyce Lucille Toler and after her death married Carol Miller Baker. Ruffin and Baker were married for thirteen years until his death on April 30, 2009."

mods.abstract: "Session I, which is transcribed, describes Ruffin's family and early life in Shreveport and Dallas, an incident where he was severely burned as a child when his nightgown caught on fire, his favorite teachers and subjects in elementary and high school, traveling for school clubs and on a trip through the West with his extended family, his hearing about the bombing of Pearl Harbor and losing friends in World War II, and his attending LSU and the activities he participated in as a student there.; Session II, which is transcribed, describes his youth and experience of the Depression in Shreveport and Dallas, his father's employment with Acme Brick Company, recreation and shopping in Shreveport and Dallas, transportation, his diverse neighborhood and classmates at Alexander School in Shreveport, religious beliefs, downtown Shreveport, Louisiana politicians and governors, C.E. Byrd and Fair Park High Schools in Shreveport, his coursework at LSU and student life there in the early to mid-1940s, ROTC and military service with the Navy, radar school and engineering classes at the University of Illinois and Columbia University, his experiences in Los Angeles and New York while enlisted, the perks of being in uniform during the war, his involvement with the Jaycees, accounts of veterans from the Civil War and World Wars I & II, and the devastation in Europe after World War II.; Session III, which is transcribed, describes classes and experiences at LSU before and after he served in World War II, military training at LSU, campus buildings, dining and recreation around campus, downtown Baton Rouge, urban transportation, the effect of students leaving for the war, dances, his favorite classes and professors, military leaders at LSU, daily life in ROTC, and how ROTC prepared him for the Navy.; Session IV, which is transcribed, relates recollections of Navy service in Los Angeles, Honolulu, Shanghai, and Hong Kong; political strife in China between Nationalists and Communists; people he befriended or helped in Hong Kong and Shanghai, including a man who wrote on scrolls and a little boy who helped him escape a fire fight; prostitution in China; people living on the streets and the high death rate; his view of Chinese culture and customs; his duties on board ship and on shore patrol; the process of being discharged from the Navy; providing medical aid to a boy who later died of cholera; trying to resolve fights among enlisted men and between enlisted men and locals; receiving mail on the ship; and his feelings on veterans of different wars.; Session V, which is transcribed, describes his work for the Acme Brick Company in Fort Worth and Shreveport; his involvement with the Jaycees in Shreveport and the community issues they tackled; marrying his wife, Joyce Toler, and their honeymoon; service as Jaycees state president then national vice president, including campaigning for positions and campaigns he undertook like teen driving safety and anti-fly and mosquito spraying; his meetings with several U.S. presidents; a story about Earl Long; his positive experiences from the Jaycees and feeling that the organization has weakened; and understanding other cultures and getting along with people he meets.; Session VI, which is indexed, discusses his work with Redman Industries in California, Merrill Lynch in San Antonio, and the Frances I. du Pont Company in Shreveport; his experiences in the brokerage business, including changes over time, technology, buyouts from other companies, female and minority employees, and stock strategies; service with the LSU Alumni Association; his perception that Louisiana lags behind; service with other organizations and boards; incidents of racism he's witnessed; information about his family; his interest in history, articles he's written, and the research and publishing of ""Under Stately Oaks; "" and interesting facts from LSU's history."
